FacilityName: Island Oasis Manufacturing, LLC - Buffalo Facility

_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: Substantial reduction of ammonia under Island Oasis management
_prev_prog_3.Description:
Island Oasis Manufacturing - Buffalo Facility's ammonia refrigeration system contains equipment to minimize the potential of an ammonia release.  The facility has in place the following for the ammonia refrigeration system:  preventative maintenance procedures and records, ammonia alarm systems, ammonia detectors and ventilation system, process safety information tracking logs, equipment alarms for system shutdown capabilities, periodic leak and pressure testing, periodic visual inspections, control valves, refrigeration hand service valves for manual operation, solenoid valves, pressure relief valves, computer generated work orders for maintenance,  and hot work permits.

The facility's administrative procedures are as follows:  periodic training for associates, compliance audits, pre-startup safety checks, process hazard analysis to address what-if scenarios and the measures taken to mitigate a release,  screening of all contractors performing work on the ammonia refrigeration system per OSHA and USEPA regulations, emergency response plan and drills, emergency evacuation plan and drills, standard operating procedures, experienced operators, sprinkler system, and management of change procedures.

Compressors have the following safeguards:  pressure and temperature gauges on suction and discharge piping, high and low temperature cut out, high and low pressure cut out, high and low level oil alarms and cut out, high and low oil temperature alarms and cutouts, high and low oil pressure alarms and cut outs, oil temperature gauges, cooling pump alarm, and pressure relief valves.

Condensers have the following safeguards:  pressure relief valves, pressure gauges, water and cooling fans are interlocked with pressure sensors, high pressure cut outs, common sump for condensers, and water treatment vendor inspection occurs quarterly.

Pressure vessels have the following safeguards:  pressure relief valves, level column with level indicator and level sight glass (bull's-eye are encased), level controllers, and level cut outs on some of the pressure vessels.

Evaporators have the following safeguards:   ice thickness control on ice builders, pressure controls on ammonia supply, PLC controls on some units, PLC alarm results in automatic shutdown of fans on some units, high and low liquid level alarms and cut outs, temperature controls, liquid level gauge, pressure relief valves, high and low pressure alarms and cut outs, emergency stop switch, and pressure and temperature gauges on suction and discharge piping.

The air purger has the following safeguards:  pressure relief valve, and check valves.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Facilities which manufacture, handle, use and/or store any of the specifically listed toxic and flammable substances in amounts above specified threshold quantities are required to develop and implement a Process Safety Management (PSM) program and/or a Risk Management Program (RMP).  OSHA's PSM Standard "Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals" (29 CFR 1910.119) is required by the federal Clean Air Act Amendments, as is the USEPA's RMP rule, "Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions" (40 CFR Part 68).  The major objectives of these federal mandates include the prevention of catastrophic releases of hazardous chemicals, especially into locations that could expose facility employees and/or the surrounding community and environment, and the mitigation of the severity of any releases that might occur.  An effective PSM/RMP compliance effort requires a systematic approach to evaluating a facility's entire chemical management process.

    The Island Oasis Manufacturing, LLC, facility (IOM)utilizes Anhydrous ammonia as a refrigerant in its production of the highest quality frozen drinks mixes in the industry in an amount above the applicable threshold quantity under both the PSM and RMP regulations.  This facility has responded to these federal regulations by developing this PSM/RMP Program Document, which summarizes the facility's compliance efforts.  Using a systematic approach, the process technology and design, process changes, operational, maintenance and non-routine activities and procedures, emergency preparedness plans, training programs, and other elements the affect the regulated process have all been considered by the facility in its evaluation.  By merging the program requirements as mandated by these two sets of regulations, the IOM Facility has attempted to achieve concurrent compliance with both the PSM and RMP regulations, as well as to enhance the facility's standing with the surrounding community.
